qas.question: When do linguists agree modern Czech originated?
What had Czech developed by the 18th century?
Journals from the 18th century have no substantial differences from what?
How much difficulty do contemporary Czechs have in understanding material from the 18th century?
What did the Czech language abandon which survives in Slovak?
At what time did modern Slovak originate?
How much has Slovak changed from the past until now?
What kind of differences do writings from the past have from modern Slovak?
What group believes modern Slovak originated during the eighteenth century?

context: The consensus among <b9_0>linguists<b9_0/> is that modern, standard Czech originated during <a0_0><b5_0>the eighteenth century<b5_0/><a0_0/>. By then the language had developed <b6_0>a <a1_0>literary tradition<b6_0/><a1_0/>, and since then it has changed <b7_0>little<b7_0/>; journals from that period have <b8_0>no substantial differences<b8_0/> from <a2_0>modern standard Czech<a2_0/>, and contemporary Czechs can understand them with <a3_0>little<a3_0/> difficulty. Changes include the morphological shift of í to ej and é to í (although é survives for some uses) and the merging of í and the former ejí. Sometime before the eighteenth century, the Czech language abandoned <a4_0>a distinction between phonemic /l/ and /ʎ/<a4_0/> which survives in Slovak.
